photo.description: The Palace of Parliament contains many paintings by Romanian artists. I liked this one quite a lot. If you know the painting's name and/or artist, please leave it in a comment. Thank you.
photo.tags: bucharest palaceofparliament palace parliament painting art
photo.title: Art inside Palace of Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: The Palace of Parliament contains many paintings by Romanian artists. I liked this one quite a lot. If you know the painting's name and/or artist, please leave it in a comment. Thank you.

photo.title: Art inside Palace of Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: 2007-07-08 Bucharest, Romania: Palace of Parliament or House of the People as Ceaucescu called it, the world’s second largest buiding in area (after the Pentagon) and the third largest in volume (after a couple of pyramids). 1/6 of Bucharest was knocked down in order to make space for it.
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: 2007-07-08 Bucharest, Romania: Palace of Parliament or House of the People as Ceaucescu called it, the world’s second largest buiding in area (after the Pentagon) and the third largest in volume (after a couple of pyramids). 1/6 of Bucharest was knocked down in order to make space for it.
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: The Palatul Parlamentului in Bucharest Romania reminds me of how the late Douglas Adams described the universe: "It is big. REALLY big." Wikipedia has a nice article (and a pretty picture) at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament, Bucharest, Romania

photo.description: During our tour a conference with representatives from different countries was on a break. We are not sure what the conference was about, but each person you see has a badge labeling the country they represent.
photo.title: Conference attendees, Palace of Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: During our tour a conference with representatives from different countries was on a break. We are not sure what the conference was about, but each person you see has a badge labeling the country they represent.
photo.title: 296 Conference attendees, Palace of Parliament, Bucharest

photo.tags: palace parliament palaceoftheparliament bucurești bucharest romania palatulparlamentului osm:way=14325732
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: 2007-07-08 Bucharest, Romania: The Palace of Parliament with the NATO, Romanian and EU flags outside.
photo.tags: romania bucharest palace parliament flag eu nato
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: I didn't take my wide-angle lens on my travels, and it's rather a shame as I really missed out on some great photos - especially here in the capital of Romania, Bucharest. The Palace of the Parliament was as immense and awe-inspiring as I had been led to believe. Photos taken on my 2009 journey through Eastern and Southern Europe
photo.tags: canon40d photography travel europe european exploration journey palace parliament bucharest romania romanian massive architecture government communist communism reflections fountain avenue treelined ceauşescu
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the Palace is the world's largest civilian administrative building, most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Originally called the Palace of the People, supposedly a "gift from the people to their leader," psychotic dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu built this massive building in the '80s. It is the world's second largest building, after the pentagon, and between the palace, the surrounding parks, and a huge boulevard supposedly modeled after the Champs Elysee in Paris, about 1/5 of Bucharest was bulldozed to make room.
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the Palace is the world's largest civilian administrative building, most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. More on Wikipedia.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: I arrived in Bucharest last night, and we passed by the Palace of the Parliament. This is a really impressive building. It's huge, and it's apparently the the world's largest civilian administrative building (The Pentagon is the largest overall), most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. They apparently built it over the old Bucharest city, that they completely destroyed.
photo.tags: bucharest bucarest romania roumanie palace parliament big huge building
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Colorful blue and orange sunset over the huge Parliament Palace in Bucharest with white crescent moon on the left side. This is one of the back entrances leading up to the premises at the north eastern corner. Several cars with their headlights on are also in the intersection in front of it.
photo.tags: parliamentpalace building architecture sunset evening intersection cars moon bucharest
photo.title: Parliament Palace in Bucharest at sunset

photo.description: Romanian dictator Ceauşescu's 'palace' in Bucharest. With a floor area of 350.000 m², it is the 2nd largest building in the world after the Pentagon.
photo.tags: europe romania bucharest casapoporului parliament ceausescu building architecture panorama ixusv2
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Photo taken on a winter night in Bucharest - Romania Camera used: Panasonic DMC-FZ7
photo.tags: building night palace panasonic fz7 lumix parliament bucharest romania
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Palace of the Parliament. This place was huge. HUGE! I don't know how they measure it but it's the world's heaviest building.
photo.title: 4598 Parliament

photo.tags: bucharest palaceofparliament palace parliament bdulunirii bdul unirii
photo.title: Looking down B-dul Unirii from the Palace of Parliament's balcony

photo.description: The Palace of the Parliament (Romanian: Palatul Parlamentului) in Bucharest, Romania is a multi-purpose building containing both chambers of the Romanian Parliament. According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the Palace is the world's largest civilian administrative building (The Pentagon is the largest overall), most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_of_the_Parliament
photo.tags: bucuresti bucharest romania palaceoftheparliament nicolaeceausescu casapoporului palatulparlamentului palatul parlamentului
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament, Casa Poporului

photo.description: The second-largest administrative building in the world, after the Pentagon
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: View of Bulevardul Unirii (Unification Boulevard) from balcony of the Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest, Romania Ceauşima ("Ceaushima") is a vernacular word construction in Romanian, sarcastically linking former Communist leader Nicolae Ceauşescu to Hiroshima. In the 1980s, it was used to describe the huge urban areas of Bucharest that Ceauşescu ordered torn down, comparing the results with the nuclear attack on Hiroshima. Following the 1977 Vrancea earthquake, Bucharest's city center suffered significant damage, and a large number of historic buildings were demolished to make way for the new Centrul Civic (Civic Center). As part of the project, Bulevardul Unirii was to be Communist Romania's answer to Paris's Avenue des Champs-Élysées, with a length of 3,500 m. Construction began on June 25, 1984. Initially called Bulevardul Victoria Socialismului (Victory of Socialism Boulevard), the road is lined with socialist-realist apartment blocks of North Korean inspiration. Constructing the Palace and Centrul Civic required demolishing much of Bucharest's historic district, including 19 Orthodox Christian churches, six Jewish synagogues, three Protestant churches (plus eight relocated churches), and 30,000 residences. Source: Wikipedia
photo.tags: piaţaconstituţiei palacesquare constitutionsquare bulevardulunirii unificationboulevard centrulcivic civiccenter palaceoftheparliament palatulparlamentului systematization ceauşima nicolaeceauşescu flag flags balcony palace boulevard bucharest bucurești romania black white blackandwhite bw architecture sony ericsson sonyericsson k750i mobile
photo.title: Ceausescu Palace in Bucharest, Romania

photo.description: The back side of the Parliament Palace, beautifully lit during a cold winter night. It was taken from the nearby Izvor Park, which was covered in white snow. In the foreground there are some baren trees.
photo.tags: parliamentpalace bucharest night trees park snow winter lights
photo.title: Northern side of the Parliament Palace in Bucharest by night

photo.description: Palace of the Parliament, Bucharest
photo.tags: clock time building architecture infrared ir bucharest palace ceauşescu romania capital europe parliament josefstuefer
photo.title: The course of time

photo.description: Hungarian Parliament Building Orszaghaz, or the the Hungarian Parliament Building is situated in Kossuth Lajos Square, on the bank of the Danube, in Budapest. It is the largest building in Hungary, and the second largest Parliament in Europe after the Romanian Parliament Palace in Bucharest. Construction was started in 1885 and completed in 1904, but the building was inaugurated on the 1000th anniversary of the country, in 1896. It was built in Gothic Revival style with symmetrical facade and a central dome. The building is 268 meter long, 123 meter wide in the middle, 96 meter high with the dome. Its area is 18 000 sqm. The facade includes 90 statues, while the interior walls are decorated with 152 statues, county’s and city’s coat of arms, and local flower motives. Around 40 kilogram of 22-23 carat gold was used for decorations. The building has 10 courtyards, 27 doors, 29 staircases and 13 elevators and 691 rooms. In addition to planetary, conference and session rooms, it includes over 200 offices. The symmetrical arrangement of the building is designed to serve a double chamber system, similar to the Capitol in Washington. The huge hexadecagonal dome hall in the middle was designed for joined sessions: the Lower House (today the National Assembly meets here) and the Upper House (until 1945). 16 statues of Hungarian kings and rulers, along with their coat of arms, ornate the walls: St. Istvan, St. Laszlo, Kalman Konyves, Andras the 2nd, Bela the 4th, Lajos Nagy, Janos Hunyadi and Matyas Hunyadi, kings of Hungary, followed by Transylvanian monarchs: Istvan Bathori, Istvan Bocskai, Gabor Bethlen and Gyorgy Rakoczi the first; and three Habsburg rulers: III. Karoly the 3rd, Terezia Maria and Lipot the 2nd. Wall paintings depict historical events, statues represent allegoric figures of honoured virtues. In the Dome Hall of Parliament the authorities have placed, uner protective glass, the Holy Crown of St. Stephen, the founder of Hungarian state. The artifact was moved here from the National Museum in an attempt to elevate the Crown as national symbol from a museum relic to a living icon. www.eyeswideshut.ro
photo.tags: budapesta budapest bogdanistanciu bogdanstanciu canon40d 40d parliament parlament hungaria ungaria hungary crown saintstephen orszaghaz architecture hungarianparliament legislative
photo.title: IHungarian Parliament Building

It is the largest building in Hungary, and the second largest Parliament in Europe after the Romanian Parliament Palace in Bucharest. Construction was started in 1885 and completed in 1904, but the building was inaugurated on the 1000th anniversary of the country, in 1896. It was built in Gothic Revival style with symmetrical facade and a central dome. The building is 268 meter long, 123 meter wide in the middle, 96 meter high with the dome. Its area is 18 000 sqm. The facade includes 90 statues, while the interior walls are decorated with 152 statues, county’s and city’s coat of arms, and local flower motives. Around 40 kilogram of 22-23 carat gold was used for decorations. The building has 10 courtyards, 27 doors, 29 staircases and 13 elevators and 691 rooms. In addition to planetary, conference and session rooms, it includes over 200 offices. The symmetrical arrangement of the building is designed to serve a double chamber system, similar to the Capitol in Washington. The huge hexadecagonal dome hall in the middle was designed for joined sessions: the Lower House (today the National Assembly meets here) and the Upper House (until 1945). 16 statues of Hungarian kings and rulers, along with their coat of arms, ornate the walls: St. Istvan, St. Laszlo, Kalman Konyves, Andras the 2nd, Bela the 4th, Lajos Nagy, Janos Hunyadi and Matyas Hunyadi, kings of Hungary, followed by Transylvanian monarchs: Istvan Bathori, Istvan Bocskai, Gabor Bethlen and Gyorgy Rakoczi the first; and three Habsburg rulers: III. Karoly the 3rd, Terezia Maria and Lipot the 2nd. Wall paintings depict historical events, statues represent allegoric figures of honoured virtues. In the Dome Hall of Parliament the authorities have placed, uner protective glass, the Holy Crown of St. Stephen, the founder of Hungarian state. The artifact was moved here from the National Museum in an attempt to elevate the Crown as national symbol from a museum relic to a living icon. www.eyeswideshut.ro
photo.tags: budapesta budapest bogdanistanciu bogdanstanciu canon40d 40d parliament parlament hungaria ungaria hungary crown saintstephen orszaghaz architecture hungarianparliament legislative

photo.tags: bucharest romania palace parliament palaceofparliament peoplespalace casapoporului egotisticalfolly
photo.title: The People's Palace

photo.description: Or, rather, Ceausescu Palace, as it was masterminded by the dictator. Strangely enough, the ghastly structure is still under construction, seemingly because nobody had a better idea of what to do with it if not continue building.
photo.tags: summer2008 vacation city bucuresti bucharest romania architecture casapoporului
photo.title: Parliament Palace (Casa Poporului)

photo.tags: palace parliament romania bucharest palatul parlamentului house republic casa republicii peoples poporului centrul civic unirii boulevard view from roof
photo.title: Unirii Boulevard, From the Palace of the Parliament of Romania, Bucharest

photo.tags: palace parliament romania bucharest palatul parlamentului house republic casa republicii peoples poporului centrul civic
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament of Romania

photo.description: PLEASE, no multi invitations, glitters or self promotion in your comments, THEY WILL BE DELETED. My photos are FREE for anyone to use, just give me credit and it would be nice if you let me know, thanks - NONE OF MY PICTURES ARE HDR. The Palace of the Parliament is a multi-purpose building containing both chambers of the Romanian Parliament. The Palace is the world's largest civilian building, most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. It represents one of the most extravagant and expensive building projects in the history of mankind; certainly of the last century. Claiming to be the world's second-largest building by surface area. The Pentagon (USA) is the world's largest building. The Palace measures 270m (890ft) by 240m (790ft), 86m (282ft) high, and 92m (302ft) underground. It has 1,100 rooms, 2 underground parking garages and is 12 stories tall, with four underground levels currently available for the general public and are in use, and another four in different stages of completion. The floorspace is 340,000 m2 (3,700,000 sq ft). Ceausescu got the idea for 'The People's House' after a visit to North Korea's Kim II-sung in 1972. The 'People's House' would be the largest, most lavish palace in the world and hold all the functions of his socialist state, as well as serve as a handsome residence for he and his wife.
photo.tags: bucharest romania building cosmos tour d300 nikon 18200vr 70300mmvr free freepicture archer10 dennis jarvis dennisgjarvis dennisjarvis iamcanadian palaceoftheparliament largest ceausescu palace heaviest palaceofparliament thepeopleshouse
photo.title: Romania-1181 - Palace of the Parliament

The Palace of the Parliament is a multi-purpose building containing both chambers of the Romanian Parliament. The Palace is the world's largest civilian building, most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. It represents one of the most extravagant and expensive building projects in the history of mankind; certainly of the last century. Claiming to be the world's second-largest building by surface area. The Pentagon (USA) is the world's largest building. The Palace measures 270m (890ft) by 240m (790ft), 86m (282ft) high, and 92m (302ft) underground. It has 1,100 rooms, 2 underground parking garages and is 12 stories tall, with four underground levels currently available for the general public and are in use, and another four in different stages of completion. The floorspace is 340,000 m2 (3,700,000 sq ft). Ceausescu got the idea for 'The People's House' after a visit to North Korea's Kim II-sung in 1972. The 'People's House' would be the largest, most lavish palace in the world and hold all the functions of his socialist state, as well as serve as a handsome residence for he and his wife.

photo.title: Romania-1170 - Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: So much marble, fine chandeliers and carpets, so much money, such a poor country. The building was never finished and is still being paid for by the Romanian people, who can't use it. Part of it is used by the Romanian Parliament. Some of its many halls are used for parties, weddings and pop videos so not completely wasted, then.
photo.title: Bucharest - 'Palace of the People'

photo.description: Note the temporary grandstand seating. It was erected for spectators of British F3 (Formula three) International Series racing on May 20th, 2007, a day before we were there. We saw workers dismantling the stands and track. Mike Meadows won the race.
photo.tags: bucharest palaceofparliament palace parliament britishf3 formulathree internationalseries british f3 formula three international series mikemeadows
photo.title: Palace of Parliament, Bucharest

photo.description: So much marble, fine chandeliers and carpets, so much money, such a poor country. The building was never finished and is still being paid for by the Romanian people, who can't use it. Part of it is used by the Romanian Parliament.
photo.title: Bucharest - 'Palace of the People'

photo.title: Inside Palace of the Parliament Bucharest Romaina

photo.description: Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.tags: romania bucharest palaceofparliament houseofthepeople ceausescu buildings architecture facades policemen adamjones adamjonesfreeserverscom creativecommons20 freeimages imagebank sharealike photojournalism
photo.title: Palace of Parliament - Bucharest - Romania
photo.username: Adam Jones, Ph.D. - Global Photo Archive

photo.description: The Palace of the Parliament, built in Bucharest before 1989 by Ceauşescu, also known as the House of the Republic, the People's House or House of Ceauşescu, is the largest civilian administrative building in the world.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Built between 1983 and 2004 under the leadership of architect Anca Petrescu (and actually still not completed, vast spaces still waiting to find a function and a reason to exist), the People's Palace, as Bucharesters call it, houses the Chamber of Deputies, the Senate, the National Museum of Contemporary Art, and other lesser institutions.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest (AP4M1788)

photo.description: Built between 1983 and 2004 under the leadership of architect Anca Petrescu (and actually still not completed, vast spaces still waiting to find a function and a reason to exist), the People's Palace, as Bucharesters call it, houses the Chamber of Deputies, the Senate, the National Museum of Contemporary Art, and other lesser institutions.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest (AP4M1788)

photo.description: B-dul Unirii was intended by Ceausescu to be a Champs Elysee-style civic project. It extends east from the Palace of Parliament through and beyond Piata Unirii. Its distance is 3.2 kilometers, deliberately 6 meters longer than the Parisian version. Its original name is "Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism". 26 churches, two synagogues and a monastery in the city's most historic quarter were bulldozed to make way for the project, and about 70,000 made homeless. What was once elegant is now, in some places, nothing but empty storefrornts and graffiti.
photo.tags: bucharest bdulunirii bdul unirii urbanwasteland urban wasteland
photo.title: Palace of Parliament seen from Piata Unirii, Bucharest

photo.description: One of Ceausescu's "gifts" to Bucharest. A huge part of historic Budapest was bulldozed to make way for this and the surrounding streets.
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: White Nights - Bucharest 2007
photo.tags: parliament palace white nights bucharest 2007 panasonic fz50 panasonicfz50
photo.title: Parliament Palace (Also know as House of the Peoples)

photo.description: Bucharest is home to one of the biggest buildings in the world.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament

photo.description: Licensed under a creative commons share-alike. Use freely but give attribution to Scott Ellis and link to www.vsellis.com. For commercial use of this image please use the contact form on my site (or @vsellis on Twitter, @ me)
photo.title: View from Palac of the Parliament Bucharest Romania

photo.description: The Palace of the Parliament is a multi-purpose building containing both chambers of the Romanian Parliament. According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the Palace is the world's largest civilian administrative building, most expensive administrative building, and heaviest building. The Palace was designed and nearly completed by the Ceauşescu regime as the seat of political and administrative power. Nicolae Ceauşescu named it the House of the Republic (Casa Republicii), but many Romanians call it the People's House (Casa Poporului). (source: wikipedia)
photo.tags: bucharest bucurești romania românia august2010 sony sonydslra700 2010 abigfave architecture arquitectura arquitetura architektur baustil architektonik архитектура architektura arhitektura arkitektur architektúra arhitektuur arkkitehtuuri architectuur bouwstijl bouwkunde építészet arkitektúr architettura arhitektūra architektūra arhitectura архитектуры mimari
photo.title: București (Bucharest, Romania) - Palatul Parlamentului (Palace of the Parliament)

photo.description: Ceausescu built this monstrosity, the second largest building in the world after the Pentagon, at the height of his reign.
photo.title: Palace of Parliament

photo.description: Biggest curtain of the palace weighing 1 tonne
photo.title: 9m Palace Curtain

photo.description: AKA People's House (Casa Poporului) World's largest civilian administrative building.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament (Palatul Parlamentului)

photo.description: A low-resolution photo from my mobile phone down Unirii Boulevard from the Palatul Parlamentului (Palace of Parliament) in Bucharest
photo.title: Bucharest 1

photo.description: the grounds are massive around the Palace - they stretch out for meters with no apparent purpose or current usage. The Palace of the Parliament (Romanian: Palatul Parlamentului) is the home of the Romanian Parliament in Bucharest. It currently holds three records in the Guinness Book of World Records 1 - the largest civilian administrative building (bigger than the Pentagon) 2- the heaviest building 3 - most expensive administrative building in the world
photo.title: view from the Palace of the People

photo.description: the 'palace of the people' built by ceaucescu... it's huge and lush and quite depressing. now houses the parliament
photo.title: palatul

photo.description: Palatul Parlamentului -Bucharest

photo.title: Palace of the Parliament of Romania

photo.description: Hungarian Parliament Building Orszaghaz, or the the Hungarian Parliament Building is situated in Kossuth Lajos Square, on the bank of the Danube, in Budapest. It is the largest building in Hungary, and the second largest Parliament in Europe after the Romanian Parliament Palace in Bucharest. Construction was started in 1885 and completed in 1904, but the building was inaugurated on the 1000th anniversary of the country, in 1896. It was built in Gothic Revival style with symmetrical facade and a central dome. The building is 268 meter long, 123 meter wide in the middle, 96 meter high with the dome. Its area is 18 000 sqm. The facade includes 90 statues, while the interior walls are decorated with 152 statues, county’s and city’s coat of arms, and local flower motives. Around 40 kilogram of 22-23 carat gold was used for decorations. The building has 10 courtyards, 27 doors, 29 staircases and 13 elevators and 691 rooms. In addition to planetary, conference and session rooms, it includes over 200 offices. The symmetrical arrangement of the building is designed to serve a double chamber system, similar to the Capitol in Washington. The huge hexadecagonal dome hall in the middle was designed for joined sessions: the Lower House (today the National Assembly meets here) and the Upper House (until 1945). 16 statues of Hungarian kings and rulers, along with their coat of arms, ornate the walls: St. Istvan, St. Laszlo, Kalman Konyves, Andras the 2nd, Bela the 4th, Lajos Nagy, Janos Hunyadi and Matyas Hunyadi, kings of Hungary, followed by Transylvanian monarchs: Istvan Bathori, Istvan Bocskai, Gabor Bethlen and Gyorgy Rakoczi the first; and three Habsburg rulers: III. Karoly the 3rd, Terezia Maria and Lipot the 2nd. Wall paintings depict historical events, statues represent allegoric figures of honoured virtues. In the Dome Hall of Parliament the authorities have placed, uner protective glass, the Holy Crown of St. Stephen, the founder of Hungarian state. The artifact was moved here from the National Museum in an attempt to elevate the Crown as national symbol from a museum relic to a living icon. www.eyeswideshut.ro
photo.tags: budapesta budapest bogdanistanciu bogdanstanciu canon40d 40d parliament parlament hungaria ungaria hungary crown saintstephen orszaghaz architecture hungarianparliament legislative
photo.title: Hungarian Parliament Building - The Holy Crown

photo.description: This floor piece is made up of different coloured marble from all over Romania. The pink stuff is rare.
photo.title: Palace of the Parliament Romanian Marble Floor-2

photo.description: The Presidential Palace. One of the largest buildings in the world. Rather a few dead dogs were lying around here, giving off quite a smell.

photo.description: PLEASE, no multi invitations, glitters or self promotion in your comments, THEY WILL BE DELETED. My photos are FREE for anyone to use, just give me credit and it would be nice if you let me know, thanks - NONE OF MY PICTURES ARE HDR. One of the many hallways inside the Palace of the Parliament, marble everywhere.
